unnormalised: ## Aiyyo! Did You Just Leave Your Saree Hanging? (Cart Abandonment Woes!)
normalised: ## Aiyyo! Did You Just Leave Your Saree Hanging? (Cart Abandonment Woes!)

unnormalised: Picture this: It's Diwali. You're scrolling through Myntra, ready to deck yourself out in the finest silk. You find the perfect Banarasi saree, the one that'll make even your neighbours, the Sharmas, green with envy. You add it to your cart, maybe even throw in a matching jhumka or two. Then... *poof*... You vanish!

unnormalised: Sounds familiar, right? We've all been there. We call it cart abandonment, and in the e-commerce world, it's like finding a samosa lying uneaten on the floor - utterly heartbreaking! It’s like the climax of a Bollywood film – the hero almost gets the girl (that saree!), then BAM! Cut to black screen. Tragedy!

unnormalised: Why does this happen? Maybe auntyji called with urgent gossip about the Gupta family. Or maybe you remembered your UPI limit is still stuck at Rs. 2,000 after that impulsive chai run you did yesterday. Perhaps you just got distracted by a cute cat video. Who knows? Life in India is unpredictable!

unnormalised: But listen up, online retailers! Just like Raj in DDLJ wouldn't give up on Simran, you shouldn't give up on your abandoned carts.
normalised: But listen up, online retailers! Just like Raj in D D L J wouldn't give up on Simran, you shouldn't give up on your abandoned carts.

unnormalised: Here's the thing: that saree, that pressure cooker, that autographed picture of Sachin Tendulkar – people put it in their cart for a REASON. They were interested! Maybe all they need is a little nudge. A friendly email saying, "Hey Ram! Still dreaming of that Lehenga Choli?" with a cheeky picture of the garment can do wonders.

unnormalised: Offer a small discount, free shipping to Panipat, or even just remind them how good they'll look at the next kitty party. Don't let that cart sit abandoned like a dusty file in a government office! Reclaim those sales! Because in the end, happy customers are the real "Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge" of e-commerce. You want to take home the bride (the sale!), not leave her stranded in a virtual mandap.
